text: Treachery - and indeed scorpion-husbandry - can be taught and learned like many other skills.
The man who designed the Tomb Kings' elaborate crypts and vaults was just far too skilled to be allowed to rest in his own.
Bearing witness to men's downfall, he judges their worthiness to serve his master-deity from beyond the grave.
What courageous heart has he who serves the God of Earth and Strength.
Khemri's noble class still possess much of their former presence and power, even after death.
This knot of life at once untie: poor venomous fool, be angry and dispatch.
The acolytes of the Great Father wield his burning power in Ptra's name, their skin shining brilliantly in the white-hot desert sun.
Where once he dug graves, now he toils eternally.
As if the Tomb Kings' skeletal slave-sailors were not obedient and tireless enough, an extremely hard taskmaster whips them into shape and on to greater achievement.
An imposing monument to Nehekhara's former power, now living once again in service of its Lords.
Someone with lifelong, intimate knowledge of the seas and coasts, and a little artistic flair, can prove most useful.
All this one needs is a small space, off to one side, and plenty of samples to work with.
As the Undead rip apart their victims they feast on the organs that spill forth – regaining strength in the process.
An assassin's services will always be in demand, assuming they survive the training…
Anath Raema's savage children can break enemy lines with tooth and claw. This one ensures their obedience in battle.
There are always those in need of protection from the machinations of their enemies… or indeed their friends.
The favour of the Pleasure Prince is much coveted amongst his acolytes.
What's that? Pleasure and pain… indivisible? I see the truth of it...
It is sometimes necessary to employ silver-tongued diplomacy to achieve one's desired ends.
Slaanesh offers great power to those who have the resolve to grasp it.
This one lives for the day when the last High-Elf dies screaming in agony upon Khaine's altar.
The Balefiend's sorceries may seem crude and ritualistic compared to others, but they are no less potent.
Nothing reinforces a Dark Elf's sense of superiority (and security) quite so much as knowing not only that his enemy has perished, but also where the body is buried.
You should never trust a wolf with your livestock.
When your rulers consider themselves above such low professions, there is money to be made for the wily merchant.
The adagio will, quite literally, tear your heart out…
Cruelty and excess have a certain rhythm.
Depravity's melody is the sweetest of tunes to Dark Elf ears.
The profits of murder go beyond merely removing one's rivals from the field of play.
Someone needs to ensure that enslaved captives do not - cannot - run away, and occasionally feed them just enough to remain productive.
When the deeds of old can be erased by a cleverly-spoken word, what need is there for integrity and law?
He's the very likeness of Khaine himself! I should know - slaving and doing for him all these years.
Beaten by lash and scourge, brutally driven forth into servitude and torment. There is no release, not even death.
A captured High Elf is the most valuable of prizes; a wealthy slaver will trade much to bring such a sweetmeat before his patron.
An Elf whose time at sea exceeds that on land is well versed in the Storm-God's ways, and knows his will.
So stealthy is the wolf that the sheep do not notice his presence until it is far, far too late.
The history of the High Elves of Ulthuan, handily converted to rhyming couplets for ease of consumption.
Someone has to ensure that the Cloak of Beards is maintained, lest its power over Dwarfen runes slacken.
I feel it would be prudent, your majesty, and admirably demonstrate your divine wisdom to all.
The agents of Hoeth seek out those Dark Elves who dare infiltrate Asur society.
His wares are forged at the volcano's molten heart, and enchanted to resist almost any blow.
Like his illustrious ancestor, this one can wake mighty Dragons and bind them to his will with harnesses of truesteel.
Unless the poison is slow-acting, his employer's life will be preserved by the forfeit of his own; according to Asuryan's will.
Ellyrion's horses are not broken with harsh treatment. Instead, the enchanted beasts serve willingly when called.
The greatest repository of magical knowledge in the world is maintained by the finest mages and scholars.
I sing in praise of Total War…
Joranor's in the lower vault, mixing up the medicine.
Like the Maker, we labour eternally in readiness for the great darkness that surely comes to consume the world.
Their origins shrouded in the mists of time, Isha's priestesses officiate her mysterious rites on the Island of Rebirth.
A relationship with the Crone protects one from harm and can even forestall the seemingly inevitable.
He watches and waits, constantly alert and ready for Druchii incursions through the passes of his homeland.
Silence, please, when entering the sacred space. And take off your shoes.
This one aspires to mastery of fire magic, so it may be harnessed at will.
I want the finest wines available to the Asur! I want them here and I want them now!
It takes many long years of study and observance to become a fully-fledged Skink Priest.
This one toils ceaselessly to restore the great temple-cities to their former glory.
Yesss - this latest scheme is in keeping with the Great Plan; the Old Ones will be pleased.
With the best will in the Old World, something capable of uprooting trees can be rather tricky to harness.
It is something that other races were not meant to disturb. Death has always surrounded it. It is not of this world.
When Morrslieb is in retrograde, that is when we should strike. Never before, lest disaster befalls us.
He scans the heavens, for the return of the Old Ones comes closer with each passing day.
It isss vital to ensssure the master isss kept cool and moist until his time of waking.
A clean pool, free from contamination, is necessary for a successful spawning.
This one ensures that the hosts are well supplied and equipped, so that the wheels of war stay greased always.
Watchtowers, spiked-pits, sentinels - the defences must be maintained lest the Realm of Chaos breaks through to consume the world.
It is important to stay cool in the cloying, oppressive heat of the jungle.
Lustria's first line of defence is the forest itself.
The sacred plaques carry the instructions and predictions of the Old Ones. It is his job to preserve their wisdom for future generations.
The knowledge and skill required to forge portal gates from super-heated star-metal is granted only to the worthy few.
You are not part of the Great Plan, ssso your meagre life isss forfeit.
The ancient enemy, virulent and plague-ridden, makes the best sacrifices.
For some, whose lot it is, mastery of the broom comes before mastery of the spear.
I was with the Saurus Warriors on the Bridge of Stars, when Lord Kroak's spirit saved the First City…
When eldritch storms erupt upon the world, it is possible to bind a Zoat to service.
They say Skaven aren't picky when it comes to food, but even they have limits.
There are arcane secrets hidden in the vaults beneath the temple-cities of Lustria. Useful secrets, to give advantage.
Yes, yes! I want it so shiny that you can see your face in it and I can eat a manling off it!
This one has a greater-than-usual care for the person of his foul, pox-ridden master.
The elite of Skaven society can live for hundreds of years, their spans extended by Warpstone-exposure, foul spells, and strange, powerful potions…
Plots, plans, and intrigue abound inside the Under-Empire, and they must all be recorded lest something vitally important is forgotten.
Not that colour-shade, no-no, scrape-scratch the grime away…
Only the privileged, high-caste members of Skaven society are permitted a female with which to breed.
Clan Moulder's hideous experiments require a steady supply of unfortunates. This one sees to their 'needs'.
I can fix it, guv, yes yes - I'll have it working again in a trice, yes yes!
Yes, master, I will tell him what you said and return by nightfall.
Vicious and foul-tempered - the result of a hideous experiment whereby Skaven were crossed with Kislevite Wolves. Very nasty. Best avoid stroking it…
Getting to the target is one thing, destroying it without killing yourself is quite another.
One less stunted fool in the war for control of the Under-Empire can't be a bad thing.
The Great Horned Rat's hunger MUST be appeased, and the ancient enemy make the most-satisfying meals.
This one probes the manling towns, instigating war between natural allies and turning man against his brother.
The deeds of the mighty Clans, recorded for posterity and handy reference, give direction and purpose to their future endeavours.
The image of the Great Horned One, fashioned from finest Warpstone and adorned with his commandments is a thing of power
They're not usually that colour - if you scrape all the grime away they're a hideous pink…
The lofty arrogance of the Elfin race, reduced to filthy, subservient wretchedness. It's a beautiful thing.
Those who fail to learn fail to live another despicable, worthless second.
This Ogre has been given the job of crafting bespoke armour pieces and a variety of nasty gouging weapons for the tribe's elite.
When it's time for a Great Feast, the loudest Ogre has the honour of carrying their Mawtooth and placing it in position around the pit.
Ogre beer is a foul, viscous concoction, made with equal quantities of honeycomb and hornet, and intoxicating enough to hospitalise a Dwarf.
This one tells swaggering tales of great bravado, some of them true, all of them exaggerated, in order to inspire the tribe.
In lieu of a proper written language or indeed any level of basic literacy, the Tyrant's achievements are immortalised in pictures on the walls of caves.
See this 'ere helmet? 'Twas a gift from a geezer I worked for in eggs-otick Caf-fay, right before I ate 'im.
This Bruiser is there to ensure that the Tyrant's line is toed and that tribal matters run smoothly… using extreme violence, naturally.
Gnoblars are stupid, but this one has shown the faintest spark of intelligence, so has been promoted above his peers.
What if we constructed a giant, wooden… Giant, master?
This Gnoblar has shown some ability in managing the tribe's purse – if he can keep his fingers out of it he may even live out the year!
This one knows that he'd better come up with some top grub if he wants to avoid becoming a light snack!
The tribe huddle around a crudely-dug pit to watch two of their best gut-barge, face-crack and fist-splinter it out until one of them either submits or dies.
Ogre negotiations are simple: give them what they want or expect their captive to be sent back one piece at a time.
Looking after the colossal, lumbering Rhinoxen is often just a matter of moving out of the way quickly enough to avoid a goring.
Haha, run! Yer eight legs aren't gonna save yer tho, 'cos yer due a good roastin'!
Anyone stupid enough to attempt to cow, or even converse, with these savage relatives deserves their extra share of the loot or grub.
Some Marauders walk openly within the lands of other races, not seen as a threat but a northern foreigner - a barbarian. But they are wrong, he is a threat.
There are many monsters in the northern wastes - creatures that will eat a man no matter which god he worships. A tribe's Beast Tamer can bring such monsters to heel… if he has the talent.
Some nobles of the mortal nations - the rich ones - take to buying antiquities and cursed items. Their ignorance in unearthing such relics is our ally.
The servants of Chaos are more than the barbarous Northmen - throughout the mortal realms secret cults worship the true Gods, and so our plans advance.
Said to have come from the ruins of Mordheim, Darksouls do not age and await the return of the Daemons that once possessed them.
Listen brave men of the Empire - pray! But not to Sigmar, he cares not for YOU. There are other Gods who are willing to answer your prayers...
Huscarls are Norse tribesmen that honourably serve their Chieftain - a manservant and shieldbearer both.
The Kurgan are a tribe that could end all others - such are their numbers. Best keep this Chieftain as an ally.
The Magister - or whatever name a cult leader abides by - is a powerful, covert agent of Chaos, tending to flocks of the corrupted within the mortal lands.
Mutants are shunned by so-called civilised societies but welcomed by the tribes of the north... and their omnipotent patrons.
Stroke, stroke - keep up or I'll feed yer to the Blood God's hounds!
There are souls that have been truly blessed by the Gods - not quite Spawn - but have received many gifts nonetheless.
The Slave Master takes the thralls taken on the raids and prepares them for bloody sacrifice or, even worse, a grisly life of servitude.
I am my master's tool - my God's vessel. Use me!
As a speaker of spells and caster of magicks, a Bray-Shaman can summon a magical servant to aid him in his darkling duties.
This hound doesn't reside with the others, it remains close to the Chieftain, a dangerous pet desperate to please its master.
Female Beastmen are rare. Oft-timid beasts, they carry the true-horn's seed and mother the next generation.
This Gor is skilled with flint knife able to separate skin from flesh, whether the subject is dead or still breathing.
This harpy is loyal to the Chieftain, and will break through the tree canopy to fly high and spy out the land.
Some Gors are tasked to look after the herdstones, their reward oft-being sacrifice at the stone they kept in life.
Some Beastmen are mongrels with minor mutations. Though they live their pathetic lives amongst men, their true loyalty is to the herd.
Nurgors are diseased Beastmen with rotting horns and blemished skin, oft-shunned by the herd and sent to bring ruin.
Chaos Spawn are not easy to control and corral, but some Gors are deft at doing just that.
This scrawny Ungor is kept collared and close to the Chieftain - attending his needs, carrying his food, getting kicked and beaten.
In a forest, there is no finer spy than a tree.
The eldest of Athel Loren's scouts have visited areas of the forest their younger counterparts do not yet know exist.
Commanders of the Eternal Guard; the finest of the finest.
A spirit of Athel Loren, while incorporeal, can be sensed by all who dwell within its Waystone bounds.
A trusty hawk is its handler's eyes in the sky, scouting for danger.
A loyal hound, tried, tested and as much a killer as any bow-armed Elf.
Those who march under the banner of the Hunter King and his Eternal Queen do so with true meaning in every step.
An outbreak of fire in the forest is generally a bad thing, but not when this one is forging the finest weapons, however.
Sometimes even the forest's chosen warriors wish their approach to be signalled; it's psychology in action.
Forest dwellers beware, lest you are watched, followed and taken, never to be seen again.
This absolute nutter is even a match for most other berserkers, such is his unrestrained axe-rage. Have him on *your* side, yeah?
From one of the seven dominant tribes of Norsca, this abject fiend attracts better-than-average Skin Wolves to the pack... and the hunt that surely follows.
A wild and unruly beast of a man, good in a fight and… well, that's about it.
Conditions are going to be pretty harsh, and the pay will vary depending on performance, but you do get to look at them... Fight well, kill plenty, and you might get to touch.
These battle-hardened, merciless warriors are experts in sacking, looting, and the carnage that ensues. Plunder and killings are their reasons to be.
I am the strongest - I am the one… and my wares are the finest you'll see around these parts, I'll wager!
It is no easy task to secure the cooperation of such a large, hairy, foul smelling beast; the same can be said of the mammoths this man tames.
Spectacularly brutal and lacking even the faintest glimmer of mercy, this one is well on the road to be noticed by the ever-fickle Chaos Gods.
While some peaks of the Norscan mountain ranges remain impassable, this man has traversed those that can be crossed.
This one tends a shrine to one of the Ruinous Powers, braving their unpredictable cruelty and random transformation to guide the Norse warriors to exaltation.
The Claws of Skael have another line besides brutal murder; as it turns out, some of their number have a nose for business...
There's always work to be done and, somewhat predictably, the living spoils of the Norscans' raids are the ones who must do it, or die!
When Varag Skulltaker fell in battle he left behind some really useful retainers...
In civilised parts, whaling is considered deplorable at best. However, whales from the Sea of Claws have a taste for mortal blood – and we all have to eat after all.
The fool dressed in motley - a symbol of Bretonnia as much as the Grail.
As Knights in training, squires assist their masters on and off the field of battle.
The keepers of the archive know the location of any account, history or lore held within the Dwarfhold's dusty archives.
The king be damned - every Dawi knows there is no more important a personage in this Hold than the Brewmaster!
Dwarf candle makers are always in demand. If you live underground you'll need light no matter the time of day - even if your eyes are suited to darkness.
A typical choirmaster's conundrum is how many verses of "She was Only a Halfling's Daughter" to regale the Elven ambassador with? The full 260? Or the shorter 180 stanza version?
What do you mean the Coopers' Guild isn't important? Tell me, lad, without our casks what would you store the black powder and beer in?
Although rarely seen on the battlefield, the Kvinn - Khazalid for lady - also known as Valaya's Daughters, are often the real power behind a Hold's throne.
A Dwarf bride often comes with a hefty dowry - by tradition her weight in gold. Which probably explains why hot-blooded Dwarfs take to curvier maids!
The ability to etch runes into Dwarf flesh will keep the spirit of the Karaz Ankor alive and well.
Dwarfs can manipulate and shape gold as easy as wet clay, and Goldsmiths are masters of this craft.
It is the Grudgekeeper's hallowed duty to keep the Hold's Book of Grudges up to date, expunging old grudges while adding new entries.
The Guilds are as powerful as the Clans in Dwarf society - a Guildmaster can control or break a Hold's trade, should he be of a mind.
A Dwarf jeweller can weigh up, appraise and rate the clarity of a stone from across a room. An eyepiece is what umgi pretenders have to use.
Miners brave horrendous subterranean conditions, and horrors, in search of iron, silver, gold, gems, and other valuables.
What in Grungni's matted beard are you doing? Never - I mean never - bring a lit candle in here again!
You can wave your pitchfork at me all you like, umgi, but I say there's gold under this farm and I mean to have it!
The High King's Reckoners travel the Karaz Ankor inspecting a Hold's assets, making sure every stipend is paid and coin accounted for.
Communication between Dwarfholds is important. As such, these young Dwarfs risk life and limb to carry messages from one to another.
Even for Dwarfs, Runesmiths are a grim sort; they very rarely take on aspirants, as worthy apprentices are hard to find.
Dwarfs excel at digging - not the crude tunnels of Skaven and Goblins - but masterful underground passages. They can also use such skills when besieging the enemy.
Elite soldiers who specialise in fighting deep underground, seeking to stem the tide of evil and safeguard their people.
A Dwarf shipwright has mastered the art of floating huge vessels of metal on water - a mystery to other races.
Those beardlings who slight their masters or fail in their apprenticeships may take the Slayer Oath in shame.
It was the stonemasons who discovered runic number-magic, allowing them to craft perfectly square stones. Manling scholars call such art "calculus".
Not an official title, but there is always one Longbeard in the feasting hall that can engross an audience with a fine tale - if offered a tankard of ale!
There's lost treasure down here, alright. Gold or gems, one or t'other. My beard can sense it. Just gotta mind those booby traps…
Dwarfs who have been disgraced, crossed in love, or otherwise humiliated abandon traditional society and seek the sweet release of death. Fair enough, really.
Whose skills include aggressive leaflet campaigns, rousing speeches, and generally stirring things up a bit…
Humans born with magical talent are dangerous and feared individuals.
Who provides painful but effective healing to the common folk of the Empire.
Any old iron? No? What about rags or bones?
The glue that holds urban society together.
No army travels alone. Who else would cook, sew or loot the freshly slain?
Wood is burned to create charcoal, an important fuel for the Winter months.
The coachman risks life and limb to bring passengers and cargo safely through the hazards of the Imperial roadways.
Some do it for the roar of the crowd and others for the money.
The bravest Estalians travel to the Empire to test their rapiers against worthy opponents.
Ferrymen make their living moving people and goods across the Empire's rivers, for a small fee of course.
It takes skill to stalk wild animals while avoiding the dark creatures of the woods.
The Empire is a nation of laws, and therefore also a nation of jails.
The acolytes of the Light College channel cleansing Light Magic for their masters.
Ship-borne soldiers, marines protect their vessels from pirates, Norse marauders, and other raiders.
With great distances separating the important cities and castles of the Empire, messengers are an indispensable means of communication.
The younger children of noble houses must often make their own way in the world, amongst the lower classes, adventurers, and ne'er-do-wells.
Ooooo master, there's some lovely filth over here…
It’s a dirty job, but it helps keep the plague away.
These lawmen patrol the roads and tracks of the Empire, protecting travellers and their goods.
Some scribes tire of reading about the adventures of others and resolve to have some of their own.
On blood-soaked decks, seamen earn their rum ration and their booty.
Honest, hard-working citizens? Thieves are dedicated to taking as much of their money as possible.
Skilled labourers and craftsmen are an important part of the Empire's economy.
Responsible for maintaining law and order, Watchmen are empowered to make arrests and fight fires where necessary.
Among the mighty forests of the Empire, Woodsmen look after the trees they will fell for timber.
Don't like some git? Then send in a backstabba, they're like nasty skulkers, but even meaner.
I'm gonna fly! Do da loop-de-loop! Watch me goooo!
Marsh-gobbos, or "boggarts", know all the "secret ways" in marshy, swampy areas. However, they're still "smelly gits" according to the Orcs.
Orc bullies are irascible, infirm and often incontinent old warriors who boss the war machine crews around.
Mounted on a giant shaggy wolf, this Goblin is a grizzled veteran, having run away from countless enemies in his time.
Greenskin encampments are often dominated by piles of poo. It's a useful material for daubing and throwing. The dung shovela has the "top job" of pilling it all up.
Greenskins don't have clergy in the normal sense, but some gobbos like to "preach" the will of da godz.
Those idols of Gork 'n' Mork that appear around Greenskin camps? Someone 'as to carve 'em!
Orcs like a good scrap in the local fighting pit. The pit boss sets up the fights and "keeps it all within da rulez".
Grrrr, we gonna get da zoggin gits! Get me prodda!
All gobbos are sneak-thieves, but this one has elevated stripping the dead of their valuables into an art form.
Orc Shamans rarely mix with others, unless when dancin' around the campfire. A lackey is there to fetch and carry for the Shaman and keep his interactions with the boyz to a minimum.
It's not just Night Goblins that like fungus, all Greenskins do. 'Shroom gatheras go and get 'em - those that survive Squig attacks, that is.
Last in the queue behind the Orcs and Goblins when it comes to lootin', Snotlings will steal whatever they get their grubby little hands upon, ensuring nothing of value remains.
The many-faceted eyes of the Feaster From Beyond demand worship, or He will not send his broodlings to serve.
A spheroid body with beady eyes and gaping, many-toothed maw, this Squig has doubtful merits as a pet but works wonders intimidating gobbos into obedience (or just eating them).
See dis? I'm gonna nick it, cos I'm a bit weeeey!
Trolls are stupid, that is a fact. So Orc troll herderz are employed to get the dumb gits where they're meant to be.
Halflings patrol the borders of the Moot, keeping away threats from unwanted outsiders.
A grim, northern land, full of Ice Trolls, Chaos Spawn, and a breed of tough fighters.
Cats are generally seen as lucky in the Empire, but black cats are said to be the familiars of warlocks and witches.
Carrion are large, Undead, vulture-like creatures that are drawn to battlefields and Unholy summonings.
Corpses not interned in Morr's gardens straight away often find themselves on the black market.
Come, child, come visit my modest hovel - it's just around the corner and there's cakes in the oven!
This thing has no mind, it is a fleshy contraption powered by its master's will, used for mundane tasks and guarding the castle during daylight.

Pass me ma spade, I'm lookin' for gallows bait!	false
ancillaries_colour_text_ovn_araby_anc_follower_undead_manservant	Many Vampire Lords keep a mortal manservant around. After all, someone needs to dust the drapes.	false
ancillaries_colour_text_ovn_araby_anc_follower_undead_mortal_informer	There are foolish mortals - usually rich, noble, dilettante types - who crave immortality and will be a Vampire's willing spy for the chance of damnation.	false
ancillaries_colour_text_ovn_araby_anc_follower_undead_poltergeist	Those spirits who are no longer bound to the mortal plane, but have thus far avoided Morr's grasp, can be tethered to a Vampire's service - for poltergeists have their uses...	false
ancillaries_colour_text_ovn_araby_anc_follower_undead_possessed_mirror	Speculum, speculum on the wall, who is the cruellest of them all?"
While they started off as destitute nobles of Stirland, since becoming Undead the von Carsteins have accumulated great wealth. The treasurer is in charge of the master's vaults.
Warlocks are those that practise the dark arts away from the overseers in the Colleges of Magic. They are the prey of Witch Hunters and more…
Warpstone is Dark Magic incarnate. Undead Lords, especially liches, will employ ghoulish hunters to find such precious ore.
